Ultimately, what do public health experts make of lateral flow tests? We spoke to several for the piece below ‚Äî which is now free-to-read https://t.co/bLkJq7wefS

When you take your test also matters. Viral loads increase in bursts, so it‚Äôs possible to test negative in the morning, but positive in the afternoon. 

Attending an event or visiting a vulnerable person? Do your test just before, rather than hours before https://t.co/bLkJq7wefS https://t.co/KGnbe3yoM4

Why don‚Äôt lateral flow tests pick up more cases? The tests are not as sensitive as PCRs, which can detect the presence of the virus earlier and in smaller quantities because they amplify the sample and pick out genetic signatures https://t.co/bLkJq7wefS https://t.co/5Cbq9FFvzI

The sheer number of cases of Covid-19 in the UK ‚Äî up 44% to 534,415 in the past seven days ‚Äî means that lateral flow tests will pick up more cases, but they will also miss more people who could spread the disease https://t.co/bLkJq7wefS https://t.co/2I9SsDUKne

Rapid testing has been shown to reduce the burden on the healthcare system by getting the most infectious people to isolate, while also highlighting when key workers don‚Äôt need to isolate. Just look at the results from a new Liverpool university study: https://t.co/bLkJq7wefS https://t.co/zLiGy0s6Cu

One of the main benefits of lateral flow tests is that they return results much quicker than PCRs. The tests contain a strip of antibodies that turns red if it reacts with the plentiful protein that makes up the virus‚Äô shell https://t.co/bLkJq7wefS https://t.co/zFFCe4uGBV

Some good news: The UK Health Security Agency has said initial investigations showed the rapid tests worked just as well with the  Omicron variant as they did against Delta, the previously dominant strain https://t.co/bLkJq7wefS

The use of rapid Covid-19 tests has been intensely debated. Supporters point to research that shows they are more effective at identifying people at their most infectious, while detractors worry that they offer a false sense of security https://t.co/bLkJq7wefS https://t.co/04TJnaC8V4

Why does the yield curve have the power to predict recessions? 

There are two possible explanations‚Ä¶
https://t.co/tRjvgqswCn https://t.co/srqT16W2JP
An ‚Äòinversion‚Äô of the yield curve has preceded every US recession for the past half century https://t.co/tRjvgqswCn https://t.co/nXqbYm9XAI

The yield curve is usually upward sloping, whereby a higher fixed rate of return is earned from lending money for longer periods of time ‚Äî but it tends to flatten when investors expect an economic slowdown https://t.co/tRjvgqswCn https://t.co/4NQ89RzFnF

The US yield curve in particular acts as a kind of barometer of investors‚Äô collective wisdom about the future path of the world‚Äôs largest economy, and has a strong record in signalling downturns before they arrive https://t.co/tRjvgqswCn https://t.co/kwjRI1hpVp

Because lending to governments in big developed economies is considered a safe bet, these borrowing rates are mostly influenced by investors‚Äô assessment of the prospects for economic growth and inflation https://t.co/tRjvgqswCn https://t.co/3iDtRlbmkW

Investors do not have a crystal ball, but the yield curve is the next best thing. It shows the interest rates that buyers of government debt demand in order to lend their money over various periods of time ‚Äî whether overnight, one month, 10 years, or more https://t.co/tRjvgqswCn https://t.co/Uzf4v1VxGv
What is a yield curve and why does it matter? For anyone new to the world of markets, here‚Äôs a useful explainer https://t.co/tRjvgqswCn

When Covid-19 hit the US, many businesses in minority areas were ruined because they didn't have a relationship with banks to receive federal financial aid.

Overall, fewer than one in four of black-owned employer companies had borrowed from a bank, and that figure fell to one in 10 for sole proprietors. Black entrepreneurs tend to bank on themselves https://t.co/gunrji83lA https://t.co/L4SMBst9ts

What questions do you have about the variant? 

Tell us below and bookmark this explainer ‚Äî we‚Äôll be updating it as we get more information https://t.co/BcgmKfozYX

Is there any positive news about the new variant? 

1) We found out about it far sooner than Delta because of the efforts of South African scientists.

2) It‚Äôs unlikely to ‚Äòfully escape immunisation provided by vaccination and prior infection‚Äô. https://t.co/BcgmKfGaQv https://t.co/JlnQnFITjd

What measures can counter the new variant and how well placed is the world to face the threat?

Border closures can slow the spread and give governments more time to prepare, but they are unlikely to be enough alone https://t.co/BcgmKfozYX

How did it get so many mutations? Scientists believe that the extensive changes in Omicron are the result of long-term infection in an unidentified individual whose immune system is compromised through disease or medical treatment https://t.co/BcgmKfozYX https://t.co/OrIWLeCwlQ
Delta dented the effectiveness of vaccines with just three mutations on the receptor binding domain ‚Äî Omicron has 15 in this region https://t.co/BcgmKfozYX https://t.co/ShZbyVDFdp

This variant has 'an unprecedented sampling' of mutations from the Alpha, Beta, Gamma and Delta variants.

These mutations help the virus circumvent a person‚Äôs immune defences as the body is trained by vaccines/prior infection to fight the original strain https://t.co/BcgmKfozYX

Why is Omicron causing such alarm? 

One concern is the speed at which the variant is spreading. Daily cases have more than tripled in South Africa since Tuesday, with 2,828 cases recorded on Friday https://t.co/BcgmKfozYX https://t.co/YQ0HsEHQmE

ü¶† The coronavirus variant Omicron emerged in southern Africa.
